articles.headline: Stuck in the Sandwich
articles.snippet: Many of us are supporting parents and children while wondering about our own financial future. But with some planning, there is cause to be optimistic.
articles.abstract: Many of us are supporting parents and children while wondering about our own financial future. But with some planning, there is cause to be optimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE’S the way our financial lives were supposed to look right about now: Our parents would be living comfortably off their pensions, while their investments hummed along at a smooth 6 percent annual return, building toward our inevitable six-figure inheritance.

articles.headline: Obama to Visit India, and Both Sides Hope to Expand Ties
articles.snippet: More than 200 executives will accompany President Obama and try to boost the countries’ economic ties.
articles.abstract: More than 200 executives will accompany President Obama and try to boost the countries’ economic ties.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — As President Obama pays his first visit to India this weekend, he may want to take his lead from Mary Kay.
articles.byline: By Vikas Bajaj and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Is It Really a Pension? It’s a Problem
articles.snippet: Social Security was set up to reduce poverty among the elderly and disabled, but it was sold as a pension plan — and that’s one reason it is so hard to contain.
articles.abstract: Social Security was set up to reduce poverty among the elderly and disabled, but it was sold as a pension plan — and that’s one reason it is so hard to contain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is Social Security a pension plan?

articles.headline: Once on Sleepy Beat, Regulator Is Suddenly Busy
articles.snippet: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is suddenly on the move, opening 419 investigations in the last year.
articles.abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is suddenly on the move, opening 419 investigations in the last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cotton, sugar, silver, wheat: in investment circles, commodities like these are hot.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: Wealthy and Worried, India Is Rich Arms Market
articles.snippet: India, flush with new wealth but worried about its security, is becoming one of the world’s most lucrative arms markets.
articles.abstract: India, flush with new wealth but worried about its security, is becoming one of the world’s most lucrative arms markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: A big item on President Obama’s India to-do list this weekend is securing a $5 billion deal for Boeing to sell 10 of its C-17 cargo planes.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Tea Party Moves Quickly to Flex Muscle
articles.snippet: House Republicans will have to balance the demands of their new partners with the need to take action in Congress.
articles.abstract: House Republicans will have to balance the demands of their new partners with the need to take action in Congress.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The incoming leadership of the new House Republican majority hardly had a chance to relish its dismantling of the Democrats before the Tea Party came calling in the form of Representative Michele Bachmann.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Jet Engine Failure Causes Worry on Manufacturer
articles.snippet: The failure of a Rolls-Royce engine on a Qantas flight was the latest in a series of problems for the engine maker.
articles.abstract: The failure of a Rolls-Royce engine on a Qantas flight was the latest in a series of problems for the engine maker.
articles.lead_paragraph: The blowout of an engine on Qantas Flight 32 on Thursday was the latest in a series of problems involving Rolls-Royce engines and analysts said it raised serious questions about the company’s ability to develop the engines for the newest generation of commercial and military airplanes.

articles.headline: For G.O.P., Big Ambitions Face Daunting Obstacles
articles.snippet: The party’s leaders in Congress are standing by vows to slash spending immediately even as economists say cuts could further strain the economy.
articles.abstract: The party’s leaders in Congress are standing by vows to slash spending immediately even as economists say cuts could further strain the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republican leaders in Congress are preparing to take power in two months with ambitious and sometimes contradictory goals for economic and fiscal policies, leaving little common ground with President Obama and much uncertainty about the potential impact on the nation’s problems.

articles.headline: For Some Bushmen, a Homeland Worth the Fight
articles.snippet: Botswana has coaxed and hounded the Bushmen to leave a game reserve in an effort to restrict the area to wildlife.
articles.abstract: Botswana has coaxed and hounded the Bushmen to leave a game reserve in an effort to restrict the area to wildlife.
articles.lead_paragraph: CENTRAL KALAHARI GAME RESERVE, Botswana — They were on the move beneath an unyielding sun, and for a while their approaching shapes seemed just another part of the desert, their tattered clothes bleached like the thorny scrub around them. These weary Bushmen — four men, three women and an infant — were nearing the end of a two-day journey, walking their way toward water.

articles.headline: Learning in Dorm, Because Class Is on the Web
articles.snippet: Online education is finding its way into more colleges, many of them public institutions facing tight budgets.
articles.abstract: Online education is finding its way into more colleges, many of them public institutions facing tight budgets.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Like most other undergraduates, Anish Patel likes to sleep in. Even though his Principles of Microeconomics class at 9:35 a.m. is just a five-minute stroll from his dorm, he would rather flip open his laptop in his room to watch the lecture, streamed live over the campus network.

articles.headline: Bernanke Fearing Fate of Japan, Not Greece
articles.snippet: Ben Bernanke has no control over fiscal policy, and how much he can do with monetary policy is the question.
articles.abstract: Ben Bernanke has no control over fiscal policy, and how much he can do with monetary policy is the question.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  By placing a $600 billion bet on the Federal Reserve’s ability to encourage the recovery, Ben S. Bernanke is gingerly trying to avoid the mistakes of Japan, where deflation has stymied growth. But the antideficit Republicans who seized control of the House on Tuesday draw cautionary lessons from a different country: debt-stricken Greece.

articles.headline: Jobs Data Highlights the Challenges for Washington
articles.snippet: The report was better than expected, but not strong enough to make a dent in the unemployment rate.
articles.abstract: The report was better than expected, but not strong enough to make a dent in the unemployment rate.
